The National Science Foundation (NSF) Graduate Research Fellowship Program (GRFP) is a highly competitive grant that supports outstanding graduate students in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) disciplines who are pursuing research-based master's or doctoral degrees in the United States. The GRFP provides three years of financial support at a rate of $34,000 annual stipend and a $12,000 cost-of-education allowance per year to the fellows, along with various professional development opportunities and access to a national network of GRFP alumni.

Applicants must be U.S. citizens, nationals, or permanent residents, and must be at an early stage of their graduate careers. The application requires a research proposal, three reference letters, transcripts, and a personal statement. The evaluation criteria include intellectual merit and broader impacts of the proposed research, as well as the applicant's potential to become a successful scientist and contribute to society.

The National Science Foundation Graduate Research Fellowship Program is a fantastic funding opportunity for graduate students who are pursuing research in STEM fields. However, it is a highly competitive grant, and the application process can be quite challenging. Therefore, it is essential to start early, seek guidance from mentors and colleagues, and submit a well-planned and thought-out proposal.
